entry.title: Cause of Alzheimer’s progression in the brain
entry.summary: For the first time, researchers have used human data to quantify the speed of different processes that lead to Alzheimer's disease and found that it develops in a very different way than previously thought. Their results could have important implications for the development of potential treatments.

entry.title: Logic Apps Standard Plan updates in public preview
entry.summary: Logic Apps Standard was released at Ignite 2020 and since then we have added a lot of features to enable better enterprise integration between mission critical systems on cloud, on premises, and in a hybrid way with runtime available on Azure, Azure Arc and locally. This post includes capabilities now available in public preview.

entry.title: Cleveland Clinic study links gut microbiome and aggressive prostate cancer
entry.summary: Researchers have shown for the first time that diet-associated molecules in the gut are associated with aggressive prostate cancer, suggesting dietary interventions may help reduce risk. While more research will be necessary, the study's lead author says findings from the team's analysis of nearly 700 patients may have clinical implications for diagnosing and preventing lethal prostate cancer.

entry.title: Cleveland Clinic study links gut microbiome and aggressive prostate cancer
entry.summary: Researchers have shown for the first time that diet-associated molecules in the gut are associated with aggressive prostate cancer, suggesting dietary interventions may help reduce risk. While more research will be necessary, the study's lead author says findings from the team's analysis of nearly 700 patients may have clinical implications for diagnosing and preventing lethal prostate cancer.

entry.title: Nurses as parents exemplify link between poor sleep and daily stress
entry.summary: A new article details how nurses who also are parents might be more susceptible than other groups to daily stress aggravated by poor sleep.

entry.title: Nurses as parents exemplify link between poor sleep and daily stress
entry.summary: A new article details how nurses who also are parents might be more susceptible than other groups to daily stress aggravated by poor sleep.

entry.title: Long-lived proteins in mitochondria of brain stabilize protein complexes
entry.summary: Scientists have taken a closer look at how mitochondria are maintained in nondividing cells, such as neurons, with the ultimate goal of developing a better understanding of how to prevent or treat age-related diseases.

entry.title: General availability: Azure Functions extensions for Blobs, Queues, Event Hubs, Service Bus, and Event Grid
entry.summary: The new triggers and bindings contain a number of improvements, including support for identity-based connections.

entry.title: Pull Request Merge Queue Limited Beta
entry.summary: Pull Request Merge Queue Limited Beta

entry.title: New Codespaces features launching at Universe 2021
entry.summary: New Codespaces features launching at Universe 2021

entry.title: Enterprise organizations can now create custom repository roles
entry.summary: Enterprise organizations can now create custom repository roles

entry.title: Command palette beta
entry.summary: Command palette beta

entry.title: Researchers evaluate whether lactate sensors can contribute to sports physiology
entry.summary: A recent article says that despite a recent history of contradictory -- and incomplete -- evidence, sports physiology is zeroing in on whether lactate sensor technology can improve performance while preventing injury.

entry.title: CodeQL code scanning adds beta support for Ruby
entry.summary: CodeQL code scanning adds beta support for Ruby

entry.title: GitHub Actions: Secure cloud deployments with OpenID Connect
entry.summary: GitHub Actions: Secure cloud deployments with OpenID Connect

entry.title: The new GitHub Issues – Public Beta
entry.summary: The new GitHub Issues - Public Beta

entry.title: Sweet! How glycogen is linked to heat generation in fat cells
entry.summary: Researchers describe how energy expenditure and heat production are regulated in obesity through a previously unknown cellular pathway.

entry.title: Four commonly used medications reverse Alzheimer's disease in mice
entry.summary: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia in Western societies and it is estimated that 24 million people worldwide have this condition. Researchers have managed to reverse the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease in mice by administering drugs currently used to treat hypertension and inflammation in humans.

entry.title: Cat’s meow: Robotic pet boosts mood, behavior and cognition in adults with dementia
entry.summary: Researchers tested the effectiveness of affordable, interactive robotic pet cats to improve mood, behavior and cognition in older adults with mild to moderate dementia. Mood and behavioral symptoms were measured along with cognition using the Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE). Intervention with this robotic cat improved all mood scores over time, with significant improvements in mood and depression. More than half of the participants scored higher on the MMSE post-test than pretest, with slight to moderate improvement in attention/calculation, language, and registration. The robotic cats also provided participants with an alternative way to express themselves.

entry.title: Potentially harmful industrial chemicals detected in US fast foods
entry.summary: Chicken nuggets, burritos and other popular items consumers buy from fast food outlets in the United States contain chemicals that are linked to a long list of serious health problems, according to a new study.

entry.title: Extended regional availability for Private Link NSG Support
entry.summary: Private Link NSG public preview support has extended regional availability to ​​​​​​​Asiaeast, Australiaeast, Japaneast, Canadacentral, Europenorth, Koreacentral, Brazilsouth, Uksouth, US South, US North, France Central.

entry.title: Extended regional availability for Private Link UDR Support
entry.summary: Private Link Network Security Group public preview support has extended regional availability to ​​​​​​​Asiaeast, Australiaeast, Japaneast, Canadacentral, Europenorth, Koreacentral, Brazilsouth, Uksouth, US South, US North, France Central

entry.title: Psychologists create body-maps of hallucinations
entry.summary: Psychologists have created body-maps of the sensations which arise during hallucinations in people experiencing psychosis.

entry.title: How a natural disaster can bring couples closer
entry.summary: According to a study of couples in the Houston area before and after Hurricane Harvey, natural disasters can actually bring married couples closer together, at least temporarily. This surprised researchers because in previous studies looking at everyday stressors, couples typically experience 'stress spillover' in their relationships, which can decrease their satisfaction with their relationships.

entry.title: Updates to our issue status icons and colors
entry.summary: Updates to our issue status icons and colors

entry.title: Dragging your feet? Lack of sleep affects your walk
entry.summary: New research finds periodically catching up on sleep can improve gait control for the chronically sleep-deprived.

entry.title: Dragging your feet? Lack of sleep affects your walk
entry.summary: New research finds periodically catching up on sleep can improve gait control for the chronically sleep-deprived.

entry.title: General availability: Azure governance policy for Azure Key Vault
entry.summary: Integration of Azure Key Vault with Azure Policy has reached general availability and is now ready for production use. Azure Policy provides the ability to place guardrails on Key Vault and its objects to ensure they are compliant with your organizations security recommendations and compliance regulations. It allows you to perform real time policy-based enforcement and on-demand compliance assessment of existing secrets in your Azure environment.

entry.title: Audit log streaming beta update – S3 support
entry.summary: Audit log streaming beta update - S3 support

entry.title: Increased consumption of whole grains could significantly reduce the economic impact of type 2 diabetes
entry.summary: Increased consumption of whole grain foods could significantly reduce the incidence of type 2 diabetes and the costs associated with its treatment.

entry.title: New study suggests that breastfeeding may help prevent cognitive decline
entry.summary: A new study has found that women over the age of 50 who had breastfed their babies performed better on cognitive tests compared to women who had never breastfed. The findings suggest that breastfeeding may have a positive impact on postmenopausal women's cognitive performance and could have long-term benefits for the mother's brain.

entry.title: A diet of essential amino acids could keep dementia at bay
entry.summary: Protein intake is known to be vital for maintaining brain function in older individuals. Now, using a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease, researchers have shown that the intake of a specific set of amino acids can inhibit the death of brain cells, protect the connections between them, and reduce inflammation, preserving brain function. Their research suggests that this amino acid combination called Amino LP7 can hinder the development of dementia, including Alzheimer's disease.

entry.title: A good night’s sleep may mitigate infant obesity risks
entry.summary: New research suggests that newborns who sleep longer and wake up less throughout the night are less likely to be overweight in infancy.

entry.title: A good night’s sleep may mitigate infant obesity risks
entry.summary: New research suggests that newborns who sleep longer and wake up less throughout the night are less likely to be overweight in infancy.

entry.title: Common antidepressant should no longer be used to treat people with dementia
entry.summary: A drug used to treat agitation in people with dementia is no more effective than a placebo, and might even increase mortality, according to a new study. The research has shown that antidepressant mirtazapine offered no improvement in agitation for people with dementia -- and was possibly more likely to be associated with mortality than no intervention at all.

entry.title: Bat study reveals secrets of the social brain
entry.summary: Neuroscientists used wireless devices to record the neural activity of freely interacting Egyptian fruit bats, providing researchers with the first glimpse into how the brains of social mammals process complex group interactions.

entry.title: Fat cells found to play a central role in cognitive decline and neurodegeneration
entry.summary: New findings show that fat cells control the systemic response to brain function, causing impairment in memory and cognition in mice. The activation of Na,K-ATPase oxidant amplification loop affects the expression of important protein markers in fat cells as well as in the hippocampus, which can worsen brain function and lead to neurodegeneration.

entry.title: Lower airways are distinct in cystic fibrosis even at younger ages
entry.summary: In the largest study of its kind, researchers found that the lower airways in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) have a higher burden of infection, more inflammation and lower diversity of microorganisms, compared to children with other illnesses who also have lung issues. They noted a clear divergence in these bacterial communities in toddlers, which is typically before progressive lung disease takes hold in patients with CF. Their findings could help providers target specific pathogens earlier, treat them and potentially prevent more severe lung disease.

entry.title: Introducing the organization-level security manager role
entry.summary: Introducing the organization-level security manager role

entry.title: Lab-grown ‘mini brains’ hint at potential treatment options for motor neurone disease and frontotemporal dementia
entry.summary: Researchers have developed 'mini brains' that allow them to study a fatal and untreatable neurological disorder causing paralysis and dementia -- and for the first time have been able to grow these for almost a year.

entry.title: Back pain common among astronauts offers treatment insights for the earth-bound
entry.summary: As more people travel into space, experts expect more physicians will see patients with space travel-related pain.

entry.title: Dependency graph now supports the Poetry package manager
entry.summary: Dependency graph now supports the Poetry package manager

entry.title: Repository Advisories Support Multiple Affected Products
entry.summary: Repository Advisories Support Multiple Affected Products

entry.title: Improvements to GitHub Releases – generally available
entry.summary: Improvements to GitHub Releases - generally available

entry.title: Hit the sleep ‘sweet spot’ to keep brain sharp
entry.summary: Older adults who sleep short or long experienced greater cognitive decline than those who sleep a moderate amount, even when the effects of early Alzheimer's disease were taken into account, according to a new study.

entry.title: Hit the sleep ‘sweet spot’ to keep brain sharp
entry.summary: Older adults who sleep short or long experienced greater cognitive decline than those who sleep a moderate amount, even when the effects of early Alzheimer's disease were taken into account, according to a new study.

entry.title: Hit the sleep ‘sweet spot’ to keep brain sharp
entry.summary: Older adults who sleep short or long experienced greater cognitive decline than those who sleep a moderate amount, even when the effects of early Alzheimer's disease were taken into account, according to a new study.

entry.title: How diet affects tumors
entry.summary: Researchers analyzed ketogenic and calorically restricted diets in mice, revealing how those diets affect cancer cells and offering an explanation for why restricting calories may slow tumor growth.

entry.title: In your face: Children’s expressions tell the story of poor sleep
entry.summary: When children are overtired, their facial expressions can forecast social problems years later, according to a new report published by a psychologist.

entry.title: In your face: Children’s expressions tell the story of poor sleep
entry.summary: When children are overtired, their facial expressions can forecast social problems years later, according to a new report published by a psychologist.

entry.title: In your face: Children’s expressions tell the story of poor sleep
entry.summary: When children are overtired, their facial expressions can forecast social problems years later, according to a new report published by a psychologist.

entry.title: Targeted prostate cancer screening could benefit men with inherited cancer syndrome
entry.summary: Men who inherit an increased risk of cancer through 'Lynch syndrome' could benefit from regular PSA testing from age 40 to detect early signs of prostate cancer, researchers believe. Annual PSA tests were eight times more likely to spot cancer in men with genetic hallmarks of Lynch syndrome than those without. Experts say evidence could be incorporated into a targeted screening program in future.

entry.title: Novel sugar detector system in the human mouth has implications for designing tastier, healthier beverages and foods
entry.summary: Scientists describe the first-in-human demonstration of a pathway that uses the sugar glucose, a component of table sugar and high fructose corn syrup, to signal the presence of calories, in addition to the well-studied sweet-taste receptor in taste buds.

entry.title: New study calls for mitigation, monitoring of common grease-proofing food packaging chemicals
entry.summary: A scientist is calling for a better understanding of the health ramifications of ubiquitous 'grease proofing' chemicals that have been used for decades. A new study based on a symposium involving scientists at public and private institutions strikes an urgent tone on the need for new and better ways to detect and mitigate this class of chemical compounds, collectively known as per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances.

entry.title: Research reveals potential new strategy to combat urinary tract infections
entry.summary: Identifying the dynamic events occurring during urinary tract infections (UTI) has revealed a new potential strategy to combat this condition, considered the most common type of infection.

entry.title: Keyboard shortcuts for quotes and lists
entry.summary: Keyboard shortcuts for quotes and lists

entry.title: GitHub Actions : The Windows 2016 runner image will be removed from GitHub-hosted runners on March 15, 2022
entry.summary: GitHub Actions : The Windows 2016 runner image will be removed from GitHub-hosted runners on March 15, 2022

entry.title: Proof in produce: Voucher program may help diabetes patients manage their health
entry.summary: Researchers measured the success of a community health intervention.

entry.title: Predicting patient death or hospitalization from COVID-19
entry.summary: Researchers present what could be a much-needed helping hand to fight the COVID-19 virus. The study shows that analysis of a particular protein on the cell surface is likely to predict who is in danger of a serious infection caused by the virus.

entry.title: Illness-and death-related messages found to be significant motivators for exercise
entry.summary: Fitness apps that emphasize illness- or death-related messaging are more likely to be effective in motivating participation than are social stigma, obesity, or financial cost messaging, according to a recent study.

entry.title: Illness-and death-related messages found to be significant motivators for exercise
entry.summary: Fitness apps that emphasize illness- or death-related messaging are more likely to be effective in motivating participation than are social stigma, obesity, or financial cost messaging, according to a recent study.

entry.title: Secret scanning no longer supports Azure SQL connection strings in private repos
entry.summary: Secret scanning no longer supports Azure SQL connection strings in private repos

entry.title: Fasting is required to see the full benefit of calorie restriction in mice
entry.summary: Over the last few decades, scientists have discovered that long-term calorie restriction provides a wealth of benefits in animals. Researchers have largely assumed that reduced food intake drove these benefits by reprogramming metabolism. But a new study finds that reduced calorie intake alone is not enough; fasting is essential for mice to derive full benefit.

entry.title: Filling half of kids' plates with fruits and veggies helps increase consumption
entry.summary: Filling half of a child's plate with fruits and veggies isn't just recommended by the United States Dietary Guidelines, it also helps increase the amount of produce that kids end up eating, according to new research.

entry.title: Aging breast tissue could set the stage for invasive breast cancer
entry.summary: A new study examines how the extracellular matrix (ECM) -- an underlying network of molecules and proteins that provide the structure for tissue growth -- can trigger invasive cancer-related genes.

entry.title: GitHub Enterprise Cloud version for GitHub Docs
entry.summary: GitHub Enterprise Cloud version for GitHub Docs

entry.title: Key protein linked to appetite and obesity in mice
entry.summary: Researchers have identified a protein that plays a key role in how the brain regulates appetite and metabolism. Loss of the protein, XRN1, from the forebrain, resulted in obese mice with an insatiable appetite, according to a new study.

entry.title: Skin stem cells get moving for enhanced skin regeneration
entry.summary: Researchers have found that the ability of skin stem cells to heal wounds is linked with their ability to move towards the injury. Their study identified the signalling pathway of EGFR and COL17A1 as a key player in the regulation of motility. Understanding mechanisms that underlie the age-associated reduction in regenerative capacity is the first step to develop targeted treatments for age-associated chronic nonhealing disorders, such as diabetic ulcers.

entry.title: Discovery of new role for the brain’s immune cells could have Alzheimer's implications
entry.summary: The immune cells, known as microglia, also help regulate blood flow and maintain the brain's critical blood vessels, researchers have discovered. The findings may prove important in cognitive decline, dementia and stroke, among other conditions linked to diseases of the brain's small vessels.

entry.title: Sponsors’ Tax Information
entry.summary: Sponsors' Tax Information

entry.title: How highly processed foods harm memory in the aging brain
entry.summary: Four weeks on a diet of highly processed food led to a strong inflammatory response in the brains of aging rats that was accompanied by behavioral signs of memory loss, a new study has found. Researchers also found that supplementing the processed diet with the omega-3 fatty acid DHA prevented memory problems and reduced the inflammatory effects almost entirely in older rats.

entry.title: How highly processed foods harm memory in the aging brain
entry.summary: Four weeks on a diet of highly processed food led to a strong inflammatory response in the brains of aging rats that was accompanied by behavioral signs of memory loss, a new study has found. Researchers also found that supplementing the processed diet with the omega-3 fatty acid DHA prevented memory problems and reduced the inflammatory effects almost entirely in older rats.

entry.title: Hiding whitespace is now remembered for each pull request
entry.summary: Hiding whitespace is now remembered for each pull request

entry.title: REST API preview promotions
entry.summary: REST API preview promotions

entry.title: Genes play key role in exercise outcomes
entry.summary: A new study has found that genes can explain up to 72% of the difference in outcome between people after a specific fitness exercise. The research involved data from 3,012 adults and has identified a number of specific genes which influence the outcomes of different physical activities.

entry.title: 'Broken heart' syndrome is on the rise in women
entry.summary: Researchers have discovered two alarming trends in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy -- also known as 'broken heart' syndrome -- a condition that is often triggered by stress or loss and can lead to long-term heart injury and impaired heart function.

entry.title: Early modern human from Southeast Asia adapted to a rainforest environment
entry.summary: Although there has been evidence of our species living in rainforest regions in Southeast Asia from at least 70,000 years ago, the poor preservation of organic material in these regions limits how much we know about their diet and ecological adaptations to these habitats. An international team of scientists has now applied a new method to investigate the diet of fossil humans: the analysis of stable zinc isotopes from tooth enamel. This method proves particularly helpful to learn whether prehistoric humans and animals were primarily eating meat or plants.

entry.title: Study discovers unique brain signature of intimate partner aggression
entry.summary: A new study used functional magnetic resonance imaging to examine the brain activity of 51 male-female romantic couples as they experienced intimate partner aggression in real time. They found that aggression toward intimate partners was associated with aberrant activity in the brain's medial prefrontal cortex, or MPFC, which has many functions, but among them is the ability to foster perceptions of closeness with and value of other people.

entry.title: The new GitHub Issues – 10/14 update
entry.summary: The new GitHub Issues - 10/14 update

entry.title: Ranking healthfulness of foods from first to worst
entry.summary: Food Compass, a new nutrient profiling system, rates the healthfulness of foods, beverages, and mixed meals on a score of 1-100 based on a wide range of science-based attributes. This adaptable tool aims to encourage healthier choices, spur industry reformulation, and guide nutrition policies.

entry.title: Americans are eating more ultra-processed foods
entry.summary: Consumption of ultra-processed foods has increased over the past two decades across nearly all segments of the U.S. population, according to a new study.

entry.title: Data continues to show that American’s need at least 5 hours per week of physical activity to prevent some cancers
entry.summary: A new report finds more than 46,000 cancer cases annually in the United States could be prevented if Americans met the 5 hours per week of moderate-intensity recommended physical activity guidelines.

entry.title: Data continues to show that American’s need at least 5 hours per week of physical activity to prevent some cancers
entry.summary: A new report finds more than 46,000 cancer cases annually in the United States could be prevented if Americans met the 5 hours per week of moderate-intensity recommended physical activity guidelines.

entry.title: In neurodegenerative diseases, brain immune cells have a 'ravenous appetite' for sugar
entry.summary: At the beginning of neurodegenerative disease, the immune cells of the brain -- the 'microglia' -- take up glucose, a sugar molecule, to a much greater extent than hitherto assumed. These results are of great significance for the interpretation of brain scans depicting the distribution of glucose in the brain. Furthermore, such image-based data could potentially serve as a biomarker to non-invasively capture the response of microglia to therapeutic interventions in people with dementia.

entry.title: Mutations in liver cells linked to liver disease and fat metabolism
entry.summary: Mutations linking liver disease with obesity and diabetes have been identified, leading to new understanding about how systemic diseases interact.

entry.title: Immune system keeps the intestinal flora in balance
entry.summary: Trillions of benign bacteria live in the intestine. They are kept in a continuous balance by the immune system, which thereby makes them harmless to humans. Researchers have been able to show how certain natural antibodies keep these bacteria in check. The findings could make an important contribution to the development of superior vaccines.

entry.title: Warm milk makes you sleepy — peptides could explain why
entry.summary: According to time-honored advice, drinking a glass of warm milk at bedtime will encourage a good night's rest. Milk's sleep-enhancing properties are commonly ascribed to tryptophan, but scientists have also discovered a mixture of milk peptides, called casein tryptic hydrolysate (CTH), that relieves stress and enhances sleep. Now, researchers have identified specific peptides in CTH that might someday be used in new, natural sleep remedies.

entry.title: Higher fasting ‘hunger hormone’ levels from healthy diet may improve heart health and metabolism
entry.summary: Fasting levels of the 'hunger hormone' ghrelin rebound after weight loss and can help reduce belly fat and improve the body's sensitivity to insulin, according to a new study.

entry.title: Higher fasting ‘hunger hormone’ levels from healthy diet may improve heart health and metabolism
entry.summary: Fasting levels of the 'hunger hormone' ghrelin rebound after weight loss and can help reduce belly fat and improve the body's sensitivity to insulin, according to a new study.

entry.title: Personality traits linked to hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease
entry.summary: New research found that changes in the brain associated with Alzheimer's disease are often visible early on in individuals with personality traits associated with the condition. The study focused on two traits previously linked to the risk of dementia: neuroticism, which measures a predisposition for negative emotions, and conscientiousness, which measures the tendency to be careful, organized, goal-directed and responsible.

entry.title: Fixed-width font support in Markdown-enabled fields
entry.summary: Fixed-width font support in Markdown-enabled fields

entry.title: Mental illness associated with poor sleep quality according to large study
entry.summary: People who have been diagnosed with a mental illness are more likely to have poor sleep quality compared to the general population, according to a large study.

entry.title: Mental illness associated with poor sleep quality according to large study
entry.summary: People who have been diagnosed with a mental illness are more likely to have poor sleep quality compared to the general population, according to a large study.

entry.title: Improvements to the GitHub app in Microsoft Teams
entry.summary: We added support to receive notifications for updates from releases, branches, and repositories in the GitHub app in Microsoft Teams. You can now subscribe to your repository in your Microsoft Teams channel or Personal chat

entry.title: Nearly 6 million children are driven into severe hunger by the hot, dry shifts of a strong el Niño
entry.summary: Up to three times more children suffer severe hunger with each El Niño than from COVID-19. El Niño events provide a snapshot of the future under climate change and chronicle the lack of proactive policy action even when climate events are predictable.

entry.title: Rye a better choice than wheat for weight loss
entry.summary: Eating whole grain rye products instead of refined wheat alternatives can offer worthwhile health benefits. Researchers recently published a study showing that people who ate high-fiber products made from whole grain rye lost more body fat and overall weight than those who ate corresponding products made from refined wheat.

entry.title: Mushroom consumption may lower risk of depression
entry.summary: Mushrooms have been making headlines due to their many health advantages. Not only do they lower one's risk of cancer and premature death, but new research also reveals that these super-foods may benefit a person's mental health.

entry.title: Unraveling the mystery of why we overeat
entry.summary: Researchers are examining neurons and hormones associated with eating too much. This study is another step in understanding the brain circuits involved in eating disorders.

entry.title: Research review shows intermittent fasting works for weight loss, health changes
entry.summary: Intermittent fasting can produce clinically significant weight loss as well as improve metabolic health in individuals with obesity, according to a new study.

entry.title: Research review shows intermittent fasting works for weight loss, health changes
entry.summary: Intermittent fasting can produce clinically significant weight loss as well as improve metabolic health in individuals with obesity, according to a new study.

entry.title: White matter integrity disrupted in people with Alzheimer’s gene mutation
entry.summary: The structural integrity of the brain's white matter as measured with an advanced MRI technique is lower in cognitively normal people who carry a genetic mutation associated with Alzheimer's disease than it is in non-carriers, according to a new study. Researchers said the findings show the promise of widely available imaging techniques in helping to understand early structural changes in the brain before symptoms of dementia become apparent.

entry.title: Is low-fat or whole-fat milk better for kids? Science says it makes no difference
entry.summary: A new study has found whole fat dairy is just as good for kids as low-fat.

entry.title: GitHub Actions: Granular personal access token scopes for self-hosted runners in enterprises
entry.summary: GitHub Actions: Granular personal access token scopes for self-hosted runners in enterprises

entry.title: Improved notification email titles for issues and PRs
entry.summary: Improved notification email titles for issues and PRs

entry.title: Set via API whether a repository allows forking
entry.summary: Set via API whether a repository allows forking

entry.title: Easier to search branches by exact name
entry.summary: Easier to search branches by exact name

entry.title: All repositories are labeled public, private, or internal
entry.summary: All repositories are labeled public, private, or internal

entry.title: Winter-swimming Scandinavian men can teach us how the body adapts to extreme heat and cold
entry.summary: The Scandinavian winter swimming culture combines brief dips in cold water with hot sauna sessions -- and now, a study of young men who participate regularly in these polar plunges finds that winter swimming may allow the body to adapt to extreme temperatures. The findings suggest that routinely alternating swims or dips in chilly water with sauna sessions might affect how brown fat, also known as brown adipose tissue (BAT), burns energy and produces heat.

entry.title: Precision medicine data dive shows diuretic pill may be viable to test as Alzheimer's treatment
entry.summary: A commonly available, FDA-approved oral diuretic pill may be a potential candidate for an Alzheimer's disease treatment for those who are at genetic risk, according to new findings.

entry.title: Researchers find warning signs for dementia in the blood
entry.summary: Researchers have identified molecules in the blood that can indicate impending dementia. Their findings are based on human studies and laboratory experiments. The biomarker is based on measuring levels of so-called microRNAs. According to the study data, microRNAs could potentially also be targets for dementia therapy.

entry.title: Sleep loss does not impact ability to assess emotional information
entry.summary: It's no secret that going without sleep can affect people's mood, but a new study shows it does not interfere with their ability to evaluate emotional situations. It is often assumed that feeling more negative will color people's experience of emotional images and events in the environment around them. However, researchers found that while going 24 hours without sleep impacted study participants' mood, it did not change their performance on tests evaluating their ability to process emotional words and images.

entry.title: Public preview: Dynamic concurrency in Azure Functions
entry.summary: Azure Functions dynamic concurrency feature simplifies configuring concurrency for your function apps.

entry.title: Alzheimer's and COVID-19 share a genetic risk factor, study finds
entry.summary: An anti-viral gene that impacts the risk of both Alzheimer's disease and severe COVID-19 has been identified by researchers.

entry.title: Checkout.com and FullStory are now GitHub secret scanning partners
entry.summary: Checkout.com and FullStory are now GitHub secret scanning partners

entry.title: npm CLI upgraded to version 8
entry.summary: npm CLI upgraded to version 8

entry.title: ‘Gut bugs’ can drive prostate cancer growth and treatment resistance
entry.summary: Common gut bacteria can become 'hormone factories' - fuelling prostate cancer and making it resistant to treatment, a new study shows. Scientists revealed how gut bacteria contribute to the progression of advanced prostate cancers and their resistance to hormone therapy -- by providing an alternative source of growth-promoting androgens, or male hormones. The findings, once further validated in the clinic, could provide new opportunities for the treatment of prostate cancer through manipulation of the microbiome.

entry.title: A 'cousin' of Viagra reduces obesity by stimulating cells to burn fat
entry.summary: Researchers have found that a drug first developed to treat Alzheimer's disease, schizophrenia and sickle cell disease reduces obesity and fatty liver in mice and improves their heart function -- without changes in food intake or daily activity.

entry.title: A 'cousin' of Viagra reduces obesity by stimulating cells to burn fat
entry.summary: Researchers have found that a drug first developed to treat Alzheimer's disease, schizophrenia and sickle cell disease reduces obesity and fatty liver in mice and improves their heart function -- without changes in food intake or daily activity.

entry.title: Clean air matters for a healthy brain
entry.summary: Researchers say their studies on air pollution and cognitive decline -- one involving humans and one with mice -- provide evidence that cleaner air may reduce risk for Alzheimer's and other dementias.

entry.title: Beyond childhood: Picky eating in college students
entry.summary: Looking beyond the picky eating of childhood, researchers looked at this behavior in college students. Self-identified picky eaters ate significantly less fiber and vegetables and reported greater levels of social phobia than non-picky eaters, according to a new study. Social phobia is the fear of being evaluated during everyday activities by others.

entry.title: GitHub Actions: Workflows triggered by Dependabot PRs will respect permissions key in workflows
entry.summary: GitHub Actions: Workflows triggered by Dependabot PRs will respect permissions key in workflows

entry.title: Azure Functions Python 3.9 support is now generally available
entry.summary: Python developers can now take advantage of the version enhancements in Python 3.9 using Azure Functions.

entry.title: Toxic fatty acids to blame for brain cell death after injury
entry.summary: Cells that normally nourish healthy brain cells called neurons release toxic fatty acids after neurons are damaged, a new study in rodents shows. This phenomenon is likely the driving factor behind most, if not all, diseases that affect brain function, as well as the natural breakdown of brain cells seen in aging, researchers say.

entry.title: Export Organization Members
entry.summary: Export Organization Members

entry.title: Deprecation Notice: Codes of Conduct API preview
entry.summary: Deprecation Notice: Codes of Conduct API preview

entry.title: Dependency review is generally available
entry.summary: Dependency review is generally available

entry.title: Color-coded nutrition labels and warnings linked to more healthful purchases
entry.summary: A new analysis has integrated findings from 134 studies of the impact of color-coded nutrition labels and warnings found on the front of some food packaging, indicating that these labels do indeed appear to encourage more healthful purchases.

entry.title: The npm registry requires TLS 1.2 or higher
entry.summary: The npm registry requires TLS 1.2 or higher

entry.title: Cancer chemotherapy drug reverses Alzheimer’s symptoms in mice
entry.summary: A drug commonly used to treat cancer can restore memory and cognitive function in mice that display symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, new research has found. The drug, Axitinib, inhibits growth of new blood vessels in the brain -- a feature shared by both cancer tumors and Alzheimer's disease. This hallmark represents a new target for Alzheimer's therapies. Mice that underwent the therapy not only exhibited a reduction in blood vessels and other Alzheimer's markers in their brains, they also performed remarkably well in tests designed to measure learning and memory.

entry.title: GitHub Actions: DRY your GitHub Actions configuration by reusing workflows
entry.summary: GitHub Actions: DRY your GitHub Actions configuration by reusing workflows

entry.title: A Redesigned Explore tab on GitHub Mobile
entry.summary: A Redesigned Explore tab on GitHub Mobile

entry.title: Ketone supplement might be a novel therapeutic for boosting brain function in obesity
entry.summary: New research has shown that ketone supplements may be a novel therapeutic strategy for protecting and improving brain health in people with obesity.

entry.title: Research shows exercise-related proteins can suppress tumor growth
entry.summary: New research shows bed and rest might not be the best treatment for people suffering from cancer -- in fact, the opposite may be true. Researchers have discovered the proteins created by the body when exercising - called myokines -- can suppress tumor growth and even help actively fight cancerous cells.

entry.title: Research shows exercise-related proteins can suppress tumor growth
entry.summary: New research shows bed and rest might not be the best treatment for people suffering from cancer -- in fact, the opposite may be true. Researchers have discovered the proteins created by the body when exercising - called myokines -- can suppress tumor growth and even help actively fight cancerous cells.

entry.title: Natural compound in basil may protect against Alzheimer’s disease pathology
entry.summary: Fenchol, a natural compound abundant in some plants including basil, can help protect the brain against Alzheimer's disease pathology, a preclinical study suggests. The team discovered a sensing mechanism associated with the gut microbiome that explains how fenchol reduces neurotoxicity in the Alzheimer's brain.

entry.title: Improvements to GitHub Releases – public beta
entry.summary: Improvements to GitHub Releases - public beta

entry.title: Brain-circuit discovery may help explain sex differences in binge drinking
entry.summary: A brain circuit that works as a 'brake' on binge alcohol drinking may help explain male-female differences invulnerability to alcohol use disorders, according to a preclinical study.

entry.title: The push webhook payload provides a consistent head_commit on tag creation
entry.summary: The push webhook payload provides a consistent head_commit on tag creation

entry.title: Age and aging have critical effects on the gut microbiome
entry.summary: Researchers have found that aging produces significant changes in the microbiome of the human small intestine distinct from those caused by medications or illness burden.

entry.title: What you need to know about urinary tract infections
entry.summary: More than half of U.S. women will experience at least one urinary tract infection (UTI) in their lifetimes, while a quarter will have a subsequent infection. Recurrent urinary tract infections are defined as two or more infections in six months or three or more in a year.

entry.title: Scientists discover 14 genes that cause obesity
entry.summary: The discovery of genes that directly cause obesity could pave the way for treatments for a condition that affects more than 40% of American adults.
